Under Status, as a source ol obligation, be groups the family relations ol husband and wile, and parent and child 3 but the incorrectness ol this had been long before shown hy Savigny (System ξ 58), who remarks that these relations, and that produced by contract or delict, are altogether disparate; the latter being the partial and temporary subjection oi one person to the will oi another, the former being permanent, and having a content natural and moral as well as legal: its legal content being not so much the personal right against the other party as a real right to non-disturbance by the world at large ¹.

Important changes had talren place in the law comprised in this second Book since the time ol Gaius. In respect os modes oi acquisition the ius gentium had reaped another triumph ; in iure cessio and mancipatio, the oldest titles ol the ius civile, which had already become practically obsolete, were sormally abolished by Justinian, who also swept away, in the train oi the latter, a trouble· some distinction and much antiquated learning. The simplification of law effected by the recognition os traditio or mere delivery as the universal mode of conveying res singulae is however perhaps no more to be admired than Justinian's masterly codification, or more properly reform, of the law ol Usucapio or Prescription‚ which had hitherto consisted oi two different sets ol rules, the one civil, the other praetoriam whose divergence had been occasioned hythe absurd survival os the doctrine that provincial soil could not be owned by private individuals. The great change in the proprietary rights oi filiifamilias, initiated under Constantine by the institution oi quasi- castreuse and adventitium peculium, was consummated by Justinian himself ; the survival of the patria potestas was thus made tolerable by the partial surrender oi one ol its most valuable privileges. The direct acquisition os possession, and so ol ownership through agents, had been sanctioned by a constitution ol Severus, based upon a con· sensus among the jurists, who in Gaius' time had been divided upon the question; and the interests ol mortgagors were carelully guarded by Justinian's regulations as to the exercise os powers of sale and ioreclosure.
